metadata.product: COSORI Pro II Air Fryer Oven Combo, 5.8QT

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** David

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Parker ---

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Good afternoon, Parker. Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is David, and I'm with the product development team here at COSORI. We really value customer feedback, especially from our long-term users like yourself, to help us understand what's working well and where we can improve.

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Of course, David. Happy to help. I've definitely put your air fryer through its paces over the last year, so I have some thoughts.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Excellent! We appreciate that. To start, could you tell me a little bit about what initially led you to purchase the COSORI Pro II? What were you hoping it would help you achieve in your kitchen?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Hmm, let's see. Well, as a mom of three, mealtime is, uh, well, it's a constant challenge, honestly. We were looking for ways to make dinners easier and, frankly, healthier. We love crispy food, like chicken tenders, fries, that sort of thing, but I just couldn't justify the mess and the… the guilt, really, of deep-frying all the time. So, the air fryer seemed like a good middle-ground. And speed, definitely speed was a big factor. School nights are just... crazy.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I can certainly understand that. Many of our customers share similar motivations. So, you mentioned health and convenience. Were there any specific alternatives you considered before landing on the COSORI Pro II, or was an air fryer always at the top of your list?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** We actually looked at a few different brands. I think Ninja was one, maybe Philips? But, uh, the COSORI Pro II seemed to hit the sweet spot for capacity and features without being overly complicated. And the reviews were generally really strong for performance. Plus, my sister-in-law had an older COSORI model and raved about it, so that personal recommendation definitely carried some weight. It wasn't the cheapest, but it also wasn't the most expensive, and it felt like a good investment for something we knew we’d use a lot.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That’s valuable insight, especially the word-of-mouth component. And since purchasing, how frequently would you say you use the air fryer, and what are some of your go-to dishes?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Oh, gosh, frequently is an understatement. I'd say probably five or six nights a week, at least for some component of dinner. Sometimes it's the whole meal, sometimes just a side. We do a lot of chicken: chicken tenders, wings, sometimes even a couple of chicken breasts. Roasted vegetables are fantastic in it – broccoli, Brussels sprouts, sweet potato fries. And, um, yeah, frozen convenience foods like fish sticks or pre-made spring rolls, they come out so much better than in the oven. It's really become our primary method for anything we want crispy without being drenched in oil.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That’s impressive usage! You mentioned it performing better than the oven for those crispy items. Could you elaborate a bit on that? What specifically makes the air fryer superior in those cases?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Hmm, yeah. Well, with the oven, you just don't get that even, all-around crispness, you know? Things often come out a little… soggy, or you have to flip them multiple times, and even then, it's not the same. The air fryer, because of that hot air circulation, it just envelops the food. So chicken tenders, for example, they’re golden brown and crispy on all sides, but still super moist inside. And it's much faster. An oven takes forever to preheat and then cook. The COSORI Pro II is ready in minutes. That quick preheat is a game-changer on a Tuesday night when everyone’s starving.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** "Game-changer" – that's high praise. And it sounds like the quick preheat and consistent results have genuinely integrated into your family's mealtime routine. You also mentioned in your review that the digital controls are intuitive and cleaning is easy. Could you tell me if those aspects have continued to meet your expectations?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Absolutely, yes. The digital controls are great. When we first got it, I used the presets a lot, especially for things like fries or chicken. But now that I'm more comfortable, I definitely customize the time and temperature more often. It's still really easy to adjust. And cleaning? Honestly, it's fantastic. The non-stick basket and crisper plate usually just need a quick scrub with a sponge, or I can toss them in the dishwasher. Coming from thinking about potentially having a deep fryer, the clean-up is non-existent by comparison. So, yes, definitely met expectations there.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's great to hear. Now, moving to the areas where you felt there was "room for small improvements," you highlighted a few points. The first was the non-stick coating on the crisper plate. Could you describe in a bit more detail what you're seeing and what your concerns are there?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Sure. So, it's not like… flaking off into our food or anything dramatic like that. But after about a year of using it so frequently, I've noticed, particularly around the very edges of the crisper plate where it sits inside the basket, there are some minor wear marks. It almost looks like the coating is thinning or slightly abrading in those spots. I'm very careful; I only use silicone tongs and sponges to clean it. My main concern is just how it will hold up long-term. Will it start to degrade more significantly in another year or two? That's what makes me question the durability.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I understand. We certainly want our products to last and maintain their quality. And is it just the crisper plate, or have you noticed similar wear on the main basket itself?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Just the crisper plate, really. The main basket seems perfectly fine. It's really those specific edge points on the plate where it makes contact, I guess.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Okay, that's a very specific detail and helpful for us. You also mentioned the overall build being "mostly plastic" for a "Pro II" model, suggesting a desire for more premium materials. Could you tell me more about what you envision there and why that's important to you? Is it purely aesthetic, or do you perceive a functional benefit?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Hmm, it's a bit of both, honestly. Functionally, I mean, the unit itself is sturdy. It doesn't feel flimsy. But when you hear "Pro II," you just kind of expect a certain level of… I don't know, *heft* or premium feel. It's mostly just plastic on the exterior, which, you know, looks fine. But if parts of it, maybe the top or the front panel, were brushed stainless steel, it would just elevate the look significantly. It would feel more integrated into a modern kitchen aesthetic, if that makes sense. And, I think, it would also *perceive* as more durable. Even if the internal components are all the same, that external touch of premium material just signals longevity and quality. For something that sits out on my counter 24/7, aesthetics do matter a bit.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. Perception of quality and how it fits into your kitchen's aesthetic are definitely important factors, especially for a prominent countertop appliance. And then there's the last point: the rubber stoppers on the crisper plate becoming loose. How often does this happen, and how much of an annoyance is it?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Oh, those little guys. *[chuckles slightly]* It's not a huge deal, but it's a recurring one. They probably fall off maybe every third or fourth time I wash the crisper plate by hand. Or sometimes if I'm putting it in the dishwasher, if it bumps something, one will pop off. Then I have to search for it in the sink or the dishwasher. It's not a big problem, but it's just a consistent, "Ugh, really?" moment. Like, can't they be secured a bit better? It's a small design detail that just feels a little underthought compared to the rest of the product.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I completely understand how those minor, recurring annoyances can add up, even if they're not critical failures. We appreciate you bringing that to our attention. Considering everything we've discussed – the great performance, the convenience, and these areas for improvement – what is your overall perception of the value you've received from the COSORI Pro II, especially given its price point?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** I still think it's excellent value. I mean, we use it constantly. The time it saves us, the healthier meals we're able to prepare without sacrificing taste or texture... it really has made a tangible difference in our day-to-day. And for the price we paid, I don't feel like I overspent. If it just had those minor tweaks – better coating longevity, a more premium exterior, and those stoppers secured – it would be an absolute home run. So, yes, high value, even with the quirks.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That’s great to hear, Parker. And linking to that, in your review, you said you would "definitely recommend it" to other families. What would be the primary reasons you'd give someone for choosing the COSORI Pro II over a competitor?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** Definitely the cooking performance. That's paramount, right? It just consistently delivers crispy, perfectly cooked food. The convenience, the speed, the quick preheat, the easy cleanup – those are all huge for busy households. And the capacity is decent for a family, even if I have to do two batches for fries. It's still quicker than the oven, like I said. So, it genuinely simplifies meal prep without compromising on quality or health. That’s the core message, really.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** So, the core cooking performance and convenience are the main drivers for your recommendation. Now, let's flip that question around slightly. What, if anything, would make you consider switching to a competitor if you were in the market for a new air fryer today?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** That's a good question. Hmm. I think it would have to be something pretty compelling. If a competitor came out with a model that significantly addressed my concerns – so, a demonstrably more durable non-stick coating, perhaps in a larger size for single-batch fries for my family, with a much more premium build and appearance, and obviously, it would have to maintain or even exceed the current cooking performance. Also, maybe if it had some truly innovative smart features that were actually useful and not just gimmicky. But honestly, the COSORI works so well for us that it would take a pretty significant leap from another brand to sway me. I'm pretty loyal to something that does its job this well.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's a very clear benchmark for us, Parker. A competitor would really need to offer significant improvements on those specific points. One last question before we wrap up. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being "not at all satisfied" and 10 being "extremely satisfied," how would you rate your overall satisfaction with your COSORI Pro II air fryer today?

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** I think, um, considering everything, the pros and cons… I’d give it a strong 8.5 out of 10. It truly is a workhorse, and it's made a positive impact on our family meals. Just those few minor tweaks would push it closer to a perfect 10.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** An 8.5 is a great score, and we truly appreciate your detailed and honest feedback, Parker. The specific points you've raised about the coating, the materials, and the stoppers are incredibly valuable for our team. Thank you again for your time and insights today. It's been very helpful.

transcript.speaker: **Parker
transcript.text: ** You're very welcome, David. Glad I could contribute.
